number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2013
												Let's get this party started! Devil May Cry 3 is the best. It just is. With a charming cast of supporting characters, Dante at his best, both gameplay and personality wise, as well as the best music, enviroments, enemy design, and bosses, weapon selection, and extra content of the series, I cannot tell you how much I love this game, but  I can say it is a lot. So much feels connected and satisfying, and the game just has so many satisfying moments it's enough to make me sweat more than anything else does.Shamefully however, Ubisoft ported this and they did a pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ job too. No widescreen support is lame, really bad controller support is ♥♥♥♥ing awful and actually manages to make DS3 bluescreen somehow. And the cutscene quality is pretty dissapointing too,  but thankfully most of this can be fixed. Now I can get on to the good stuff though. Dante's gameplay just feels great because he not only has the abilities to bring interesting stuff to the table, but enemies that flow around them. If there's something that feels awkward to fight, it's because you aren't thinking outside the box yet.  DT explosion is an okay mechanic too, I like it better than "DT improves style moves", but it's just filler most of the time I think.The bosses in this are really cool too, Nevan in particular is a favourite of mine, not due to her sexuality, but due to the fact that she really compliments Dante in her scenes, if only one boss could become a Devil Arm, it should be her. The other bosses are pretty cool too, with Cerberus' great music and Dante's cheeky one liners at him, those twin swords guys making for an interesting fight that forces you to think of it as a double boss; as well as the Vergil and Jester fights that gradually get harder and more interesting as the game goes on, which make for a very cool REAL final boss fight, although fighting side by side with a certain character for that one boss was cool too. I also really like how while Dante tends to be an overzealous cocky badass, he does understand what it means to actually be human and actually shows emotion as well, which is good, since Lady is a great receptor for these feelings, as well as an attractive character style, sexually, and personality wise. I also do like Vergil's conviction and dedication to his personal creed as well. Arkham and Jester are also very cool as well!  Another thing I really like is how powerful styles get to be at level 3, it really makes you feel powerful with whatever you choose, but you also don't feel dependent on them, with the strong weapons and guns as well.Playing as Vergil is also pretty cool, although I must admit he feels a bit too eh for me. I also like the ability to pick whatever level of Bloody Palace you want to go to, it's just neat, but I wish there was a boss rush mode sometimes.Also have to say the credits sequence is a HUGE turn on, ♥♥♥♥ I love playable credits.One hell of a party!/10

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												There's no question that the minute you boot this game and see with your own eyes just how bad this port is you will feel an immediate and pressing urge to redeem a refund as soon as humanly possible. However, I implore you to reconsider that course of action. For as terrible a PC port as this game is, all the severe gameplay breaking bugs can be resolved, given you spend a few minutes following the "Windows 10 Complete Experience" guide for fixing the game. 


DMC3: SE On Windows 10 - My Guide for the Complete Experience 
A Guide for Devil May Cry 3: Special Edition
By: nealiosis

			A summary of the steps to take on Windows 10 to configure this game so it will function properly with full music, custcenes, and XBOX360 controller support.		


Once the fixes are applied and functional, the pure majesty of this game is revealed. The graphics are so remarkable, the combat is as fluid and responsive as an olympic gymnist, and the game itself is devilishy addictive and fun. This game is an all-time great game and this PC edition (once you have fixed the issues) is, without a doubt, the definitive build of this product. Its a true and legitimate masterpiece of a game and don't let yourself miss out on one of gaming's greatest gems because Capcom skimped out and hired a team of incompetent chimpanzees to port the game to the PC platform.

number of helpful: 1 of 24 people (4%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												You want a challenge? You want a game that demand skill? Well look no further, this game offers both of these things. Even on Normal mode.It's ridiculous on how hard this game. So combat wise it's a pretty fun game but it has some problems.The weapons have few moveset in the start and buying upgrades for them on the first run is pretty hard. Grinding souls just isn't an option on Normal mode either in my opinion. So it's best to stick with a weapon and that would most likely be Rebellion.For the styles it's pretty much Swordmaster that you need. You can hit enemies in the air then because you'll always do a downward thrust. Later on you might use Doppleganger though because it can double your power on stunned bosses. Which is nice.For items you need to be aware of one thing. The price goes up when you buy one. It goes up a lot. Using an item and continuing a stage makes you lose the item and start over the last checkpoint. Keep that in mind when fighting bosses.As for getting the game to work. It ran fine on my system and my PS2 gamepad worked just fine with the game. But if you have a 360 gamepad you might need to look up on a fix.But honestly, I'd pick up Devil May Cry 4 instead as the controls are better that time around. It can still be a lot of fun as well.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Well, the PC port is pretty bad, but not to the point where you ABSOLUTELY can't play and enjoy it. As for the controls, seriously guys, as many people posting about how the XBox controller won't work there are still people who continue to say so. Rather than complaining, go out and get a Logitech controller, adjust the controls with the gamepad application in the main file, and you're set to go. It's like playing on your PS2 all over again. But aside from some graphical errors, the game is still as great as it was when it first came out. Using an emulator takes too much time, what with finding all the files you need or having to actually purchase the game CD from one of the few small town stores that sell old and retro games/consoles. In my opinion it is better to just buy it on here, and spend a little bit of money for a simple Logitech controller. Or if you're too lazy to edit controls or get a controller, find a store that sells old PS2 games and consoles. 10/10 Will CONTINUE to play.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												AntiMacro is better gamepad to key mapping, as it is FREE, multi OS, and supports Win8.1.http://www.webupd8.org/2013/09/map-keyboardmouse-input-to-your-gamepad.htmlHere are the configs for the Razer Sabertooth Elite:[Controller (Razer Sabertooth Elite)]START = 7SELECT = 6CIRCLE = 1TRIANGLE = 3SQUARE = 2CROSS = 0L1 = 4R1 = 5L2 = R2 = L3 = 8R3 = 9L<->R = 1Use AntiMacro to map the L and R trigger to Q and E, then map the guide button with hold, alt, F4, and release under advance.  Also here is the general guidelines on how to fix your controller:1, the top line is your device name in Windows.  For Win 8.1, you need to go to Control Panel > Devices and Printers, then right click on your gamepad and select "Game controller settings".  Put whatever name that comes up for your controller inside [].2, the numbers for the button is exactly the name of the button minus 1. For example, the A button for my Razer Sabortooth Elite shows up as button 1, so 1 - 1 = 0, thus map "0" to the cross or X button.  You can ID the buttons within Properties > Test from the "Game controller settings."3, L and R trigger and the guide button need to be map with AntiMacro as mentioned above.4, L<->R is to swap the left and right stick, which needs to be enabled with a 1 for the Sabertooth Elite (0 to disable).5, the mapping was based on the PS2 verion of the controls, so change them to your linking in the config file for custom mapping.  DO NOT TRY TO CONFIG INSIDE THE GAME, and just leave anything to default and you will be fine.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												Often regarded by long time DMC fans as the best all around DMC title, I can agree that it is very well put together and a hell of a lot of fun. While DMC4 is easier to get into, and more polished in both the gameplay and graphics department - it's no reason to overlook this game. DMC3 is arguably more difficult, and boasts a larger total weapon set along with what is in my opinion a much better setting and theme (very much Castlevania esque). In DMC3:SE you are also granted the ability to play as Dante's twin brother Vergil, who presents a very different and equally fun playstyle. There are also more total styles available for Dante, including Quicksilver (slow time) and Doppleganger (second Dante that repeats moves you do)Fast paced combat filled with many combos and mechanics, along with a sizable amount of content and replayability, it makes for an overall fun experience that gets better as you do.My only problem is the fact that the base port is very poorly done. KB&M controls are quite awful, and game performance has a tendency to drop even on a powerful rig for seemingly no reason (I mean, it's a PS2 era game on modern hardware).Regardless, highly recommended for fans of action and fighting games. You won't be disappointed.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												The game itself is about what you'd expect from the Devil May Cry series, i.e. an awesome and over-the-top hack-'n-slash adventure starring everyone's favorite wise-cracking devil hunter, Dante. However, this has got to be one of the most badly ported games of all time. The first time I installed it, the control stick's usual "LS for movement, RS for camera control" was reversed and couldn't be changed, and it, much like Dark Souls, is borderline unplayable without a controller. I can only recommend this to anyone if they're fans of the series who can put up with a really wonky control scheme.

Posted: January 8, 2016
												Recommended but for fans only ! I would even say fans that don't mind putting some effort into fixing the problems. It's a pretty bad port ! Be advise of what you're getting. Things that don't work as expected :  Dualshock 3 not detected (setup as a 360 controller with DS3/Better DS3. Work in every game but this one).  Can't launch in fullscreen. Got to press alt+enter everytime. Resolution isn't saved. Got to set it to 1280x960 everytime (That's the maximum, original 4:3 format mind you). There's some clipping on both side of the screen when in fullscreen. Ok so that's my complaint after just got out of the shop and facing that 3 headed dog. I ended mapping all the keyboard buttons on my Steam Controller and it works well enough. Gotta say that I'm a fan of the serie, played them all back on the PS2, PS3 and now on PC. This port is just really really bad but if you put some effort, you can make it work with patches and fixes by the community. Just know what you're getting into. Be advised !!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												First let me hit you with the bad news, DMC3 is poorly optimized for Steam. There is no question about that. However, with some tweaking you can get this game in playable form. There is a mod for the game called, the "Style Switcher" that enhances the game greatly with HD richness. Unfortunately, I wasn't able to get this mod to work and it's a long process of steps. The good news is that I was able to get the xbox controller working and the game playable at full screen without implementing the "Style Switcher" mod. Sadly, I'm missing out on HD enhancements. Instead DMC3 is displayed more in tune with it's PS2 counterpart. That means some jaggies even at a higher resolution. Still, the game is totally playable you just have to make a few edits, which are all explained in the DMC3 community guides section here on Steam.I played the original on PS2 and skipped out on DMC2 because I read lackruster things about it. DMC3 is a prequel to the original so really nothing is missed. DMC3 is a stylish-high action-combo masher- adventure title. It's a huge step up from the original (which was very enjoyable) and perhaps from DMC 2 (so I've heard). Despite negative reviews here on Steam I'm going to go ahead and recommend the steam version of DMC3. I would highly suggest NOT purchasing it for $19.99 and wait for the game to go on sale. That's exactly what I did. Just be prepared to make some edits in the game's files, which is a very easy process. I wish I could say the same about the "Style Switcher" mod. That will require some patience and possibily some trials of errors.DMC3 is well praised from both critics and fans as being the best entry in the DMC series. Don't miss it as it's a great game just wait for a sale!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												A stylish fighting game classic. This may be considered the peak of the Devil May Cry series. It is also out for quite the while now, so it seems hardly necessary to go into too much detail that has already been covered over and over again.Storywise, you battle your way through an ancient tower to face your brother Vergil and foil his sinister intentions... but whose plan is really in action here?Gameplaywise, this game really shines. You can achieve mastery in four styles with different foci (Gunslinger, Swordmaster, Trickster and Royal Guard), plus two slightly more gimmick-like unlockables. You acquire an arsenal of five melee and five long range weapons, each category of which you can equip two and seamlessly switch between them. This is hardly astonishing nowadays, but it still blends together magnificently. There is also the bloody palace, an arena mode that provides slaughter aplenty.This version comes with new difficulty modes (compared to the original on PS2), which may or may not be of interest to you, and with a playable Vergil. This is a fun variant of the fighting gameplay, but does not introduce a lot of new content otherwise - the levels are simply the campaign all over again, minus the story cutscenes.One thing that should be mentioned is the optimization of the steam version. I bought the game in retail originally, and there were quite a few problems with it not recognizing gamepads correctly or at all - I ended up with a JoyToKey-workaround, which rather nullified the use of analog sticks, and still had trouble mapping the controller because some buttons were not registered, some double, and some of the in-game controls refused to be changed. The steam game comes with a controller configuration application, a nice little thing that took all this work away and actually succeeded in using both sticks and the various seemingly problematic buttons. This little addition increases playability a good deal for me.If you do not have this game yet and care for action / (sword-) fighting games with a really well thought-through combat system, I highly recommend looking into this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												I definitely reccomend this game, to whoever is reading this, it is definitely worth it, even if it isn't the best of ports, and you don't have a PS2, get it, and play it. There are very easy workarounds to get the resolution you want, and to fix the gamepad controls.I never really got a chance to play this game on the PS2, since it didn't seem like a game I would really be interested in, however after a few years of being released on PC, it caught my attention, most noticeably, it's really, really high rating, and I thought to myself, is this game really that good? Short answer: YES.Back in 2007 (with a 2004 Packard Bell PC) I was just glad I was running the game, I was new to PC gaming, so I didn't really have a clue what to expect. The visuals weren't really impressive, especially in 640x480 resolution, but I did manage to get it to full screen and a slightly higher res. The main problem was the keyboard controls, they were very unusual at first, and the game also was probably the hardest one I had played to date on PC (mind you, it was probably only the 10th game I played on PC) Just the second mission boss was owning me again and again, and probably went the same way about 10 more times before, I got fed up and stopped playing, and this was on normal difficulty.A few days later picked it up again and started playing, this time I somehow managed to scrape by the first boss, and off I went, one of the best games I have ever played, and also gave me the mentality to never give up on a hard game, it's always more satisfying when the game is hard, unlike DmC. DMC 3 truly is an epic game, with cheesy (but funny) one liners and whole load of awesome action, the cinematics are awesomely done, the storyline (though confusing at times) is awesome. It really disappoints me that there hasn't been a true continuation of the DMC storyline, even in DMC 4, the main focus was not on Dante. But I am getting ahead of myself, and there are spoilers if I keep going on, and someone is still yet to play DMC 4, so I'll just stop here.Now that I have the game on steam, I had a few problems with the controls again, but this time for the gamepad, I was already used to the keyboard controls, since I played through this game before, and I also wanted to play it in 1080p this time, and with the help of the Steam community and a few mods, I got it to run as I wanted it to both the resolution and the gamepad, except for the quick weapon switches the triggers on the 360 controller are the only buttons that don't respond, it doesn't bother me much since my favourite weapons are the default ones anyway, Rebellion is just too good, and Ebony and Ivory are just the trademark guns you can't go anywhere without them. Besides that, the game looks better than ever, and I would definitely recommend you get this game, especially in a sale, since they didn't really do a good job on the port. Trust me the extra work will be completely worth your time, I wasn't into these kinds of games before, but this game just got me hooked to the DMC story.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015

Look out for a sale, grab the Style Switcher Mod, and enjoy one of the best hack-and-slash action game ever made.

A precaution:If using Style Switcher, do not change the HUD value from 1.0. It will make one of the boss fight unable to be attacked with a melee weapon.Also, you don't want it to drop below 50 fps (this may be possible even on a relatively powerful rig; it's truly a bad port). DMC3 requires good timing and good reflex - low fps will screw you up.And perhaps contrary to most people, I did find playing with a keyboard to be more convenient and reflexive, especially when it comes to changing weapons, and going "full assault" with Vergil. Do try playing with a keyboard, seriously.

Posted: October 5, 2015
												By 2015 it is hard for me to understand why this game is such a classic. Hammy, trite dialogue, a plot that is skin deep and a protagonist that is a grade A♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥bag... it's definitely not your regular AAA game. Still it has it's charm, and despite a couple of really terribly designed bosses, is a good but fair challenge. It has high action, hack and slash elements with a nice levelling and point system that keeps you coming back for more.The PC port is terrible, a true travesty. However, follow the guides an this can be running in 1920 x 1080, with an xbox controller without a hitch. It's a shame that the community is left to fixed this travesty, but when it's on a good deal I would still recommend purchasing it for nostalgia or a good Sunday afternoon fun.Back to the game, several professional reviews said the game world was massive... Don't be fooled, after about midway most of the game is just level revisits with something slightly altered. The game feels big enough, but is no Dark souls in scope.7/10

content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												By 2015 it is hard for me to understand why this game is such a classic. Hammy, trite dialogue, a plot that is skin deep and a protagonist that is a grade A♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥bag... it's definitely not your regular AAA game. Still it has it's charm, and despite a couple of really terribly designed bosses, is a good but fair challenge. It has high action, hack and slash elements with a nice levelling and point system that keeps you coming back for more.The PC port is terrible, a true travesty. However, follow the guides an this can be running in 1920 x 1080, with an xbox controller without a hitch. It's a shame that the community is left to fixed this travesty, but when it's on a good deal I would still recommend purchasing it for nostalgia or a good Sunday afternoon fun.Back to the game, several professional reviews said the game world was massive... Don't be fooled, after about midway most of the game is just level revisits with something slightly altered. The game feels big enough, but is no Dark souls in scope.7/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												AntiMacro is better gamepad to key mapping, as it is FREE, multi OS, and supports Win8.1.http://www.webupd8.org/2013/09/map-keyboardmouse-input-to-your-gamepad.htmlHere are the configs for the Razer Sabertooth Elite:[Controller (Razer Sabertooth Elite)]START = 7SELECT = 6CIRCLE = 1TRIANGLE = 3SQUARE = 2CROSS = 0L1 = 4R1 = 5L2 = R2 = L3 = 8R3 = 9L<->R = 1Use AntiMacro to map the L and R trigger to Q and E, then map the guide button with hold, alt, F4, and release under advance.  Also here is the general guidelines on how to fix your controller:1, the top line is your device name in Windows.  For Win 8.1, you need to go to Control Panel > Devices and Printers, then right click on your gamepad and select "Game controller settings".  Put whatever name that comes up for your controller inside [].2, the numbers for the button is exactly the name of the button minus 1. For example, the A button for my Razer Sabortooth Elite shows up as button 1, so 1 - 1 = 0, thus map "0" to the cross or X button.  You can ID the buttons within Properties > Test from the "Game controller settings."3, L and R trigger and the guide button need to be map with AntiMacro as mentioned above.4, L<->R is to swap the left and right stick, which needs to be enabled with a 1 for the Sabertooth Elite (0 to disable).5, the mapping was based on the PS2 verion of the controls, so change them to your linking in the config file for custom mapping.  DO NOT TRY TO CONFIG INSIDE THE GAME, and just leave anything to default and you will be fine.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												Often regarded by long time DMC fans as the best all around DMC title, I can agree that it is very well put together and a hell of a lot of fun. While DMC4 is easier to get into, and more polished in both the gameplay and graphics department - it's no reason to overlook this game. DMC3 is arguably more difficult, and boasts a larger total weapon set along with what is in my opinion a much better setting and theme (very much Castlevania esque). In DMC3:SE you are also granted the ability to play as Dante's twin brother Vergil, who presents a very different and equally fun playstyle. There are also more total styles available for Dante, including Quicksilver (slow time) and Doppleganger (second Dante that repeats moves you do)Fast paced combat filled with many combos and mechanics, along with a sizable amount of content and replayability, it makes for an overall fun experience that gets better as you do.My only problem is the fact that the base port is very poorly done. KB&M controls are quite awful, and game performance has a tendency to drop even on a powerful rig for seemingly no reason (I mean, it's a PS2 era game on modern hardware).Regardless, highly recommended for fans of action and fighting games. You won't be disappointed.

												Capcom kinda butchered the port but hey, it's still Devil May Cry. I've found that the keyboard configuration is actually really fun and effective once you get used to it. If you're new it might help since you can keep a finger on the attack, shoot, and style buttons at all times. If you're a seasoned DMC veteram who's gone through Heaven and Hell unscathed, it could be an interesting new playstyle that lets you suck at and eventually master the game all over again. Why not?tl;dr somewhat sloppy port & try using the keyboard cause it's fun too

												May i just say... this is one of the best games of all time, and best action game of all time.Yeah this port is lazy but me being the pc guy i knew exactly what to do, i managed to get this game running at 1080p and got my controller to be fully compatiable with the game after some tweaks, some 5 minute work.This still isn't an excuse to make people tweak the game just because capcom was lazy porting it.so if you're not willing to do some work before playing this just buy it on ps2 or emulate it.also if you don't have a gaming pc don't buy it, yes yes i know this game has ps2 graphics but capcom was being lazy, so yeah you'll need a medium range gaming pc to play it PROPERLY, something around gtx 750 ti should be a smooth experience, yeah i know... crazy, im serious.if you guys never played this game and want a good detailed review you can visit this link : http://www.gamefaqs.com/ps2/920607-devil-may-cry-3-dantes-awakening/reviews/85364(this review isn't mine but it adresses everything about the game that you need to know!) , my opinions about this game are 100% in match with what this guy in the link says, and i think many other people's too.Would i recommend this game? Yes definitely, its a MUST for all gamers.Would i recommend this port? For people who don't mind doing some tweaks and google? Yeah. For people who just want to game after downloading? No.If you take your time tweaking this port it should be a better experience than the PS2 version.Final Verdict (my opinion) :The Game : 10/10 Absloutely amazing action packed game!This port : 3/10 - you can make it a 10/10 port with your own tweaks, but rating capcom's work... it's really lazy.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												Originally I was a big fan of this game on the Playstation 2 and it still remains my favourate DMC game, so on sale for just over £3 I felt it was a bargin. However there are major porting issues which render the game unplayble via a control pad if your not prepared to download the software to fix them (there are guides on the web and links through other reviews). You can get it to work close to full screen with alt + enter and once you have a controller software set up the game seems to run ok apart from the  camera. This is because the developers current config software maps both the camera and movement to the right analog stick on  PC controllers.  As it stands it is only worth buying as a sale item and I would love to see a fix released on the controls.This game would also benefit from the steam workshop (if someone would release the modding facility for the game)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												With a little bit of effort and the Style Switcher mod, this title is a great alternative to the PS2 version.  This is still one of my favorite action games to date, and the gameplay is still challenging.  However, you will have to do some work if you want it to work.It's made even more dynamic with the ability to expand on Virgil and switch styles on the fly (using mods).For those who have never played a Devil May Cry title, this is arguably the best of them all.  Though there's options to start on Easy, the game can become extremely challenging.  Once you clear one difficulty, the next one is unlocked.  The hardest difficulty gets extremely hard with more enemies in each level, faster enemies that deal more damage, bosses with fatal (or near) attacks, and if you don't clear enemies quickly, the become much harder to kill.I think this is one of Capcom's best titles, even though the voice-acting and cutscenes are corny.  Controller extremely highly recommended.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												Originally I was a big fan of this game on the Playstation 2 and it still remains my favourate DMC game, so on sale for just over £3 I felt it was a bargin. However there are major porting issues which render the game unplayble via a control pad if your not prepared to download the software to fix them (there are guides on the web and links through other reviews). You can get it to work close to full screen with alt + enter and once you have a controller software set up the game seems to run ok apart from the  camera. This is because the developers current config software maps both the camera and movement to the right analog stick on  PC controllers.  As it stands it is only worth buying as a sale item and I would love to see a fix released on the controls.This game would also benefit from the steam workshop (if someone would release the modding facility for the game)

												-> NOT RECOMMENDED DUE TO ♥♥♥♥♥♥ PC PORT. BETTER OFF TO BUY THE CONSOLE VERSION ETC. <-Devil May Cry 3 is actually a fun game as usual, probably the best one in the franchise that I played. Main character is of course Dante, and his evil brother Virgil. The gameplay is my most favorite from this game, ranged weapons to choose like dual pistol, shotgun, rocket launcher, some laser weapon, and even a sniper rifle. For melee, is his very own big sword, fists, dual swords, a ♥♥♥♥ing guitar (whoa), and others that I may forgot. Devil triggers are pretty cool too, I think my most favorite one is the one that you can clone yourself for double the destruction. So for the bad side of the game, only the keyboard works, gamepad controls are broken for me, what a shame. (I'd recommend XPadder if you really need the gamepad controls.) Theres also this weapon changing from the pause menu, why not during ingame for blazing the ♥♥♥♥ out of the combo'ing? (though this is possible in DMC4, but whatever.) Rating: 7 / 10 Pros: Obvious gameplay is obvious, lots of weapons to use, a ♥♥♥♥ing guitar as a weapon (holy♥♥♥♥♥♥, Devil Triggers are game changers to cause more mayhem. Cons: Problems with gamepad, Weapon switching should've been ingame instead of in the pause menu.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												I really want to give this game a good review, but I can't because this version of the game is literally broken. Devil May Cry is one of the less forgiving entries in the series, but does crappy port of the game does no justice. Some people will try to defend their purchase that it is rather playable, but you need to do some advance configurations to get the game running with playable settings.Control support is barebones to the point that you might as well play with mouse and keyboard, oh wait, that's broken too.Graphics are really choppy and the setttings are barebones as well.The game aside is good but this port is horrendous.I got this game with a DMC 4 bundle so I don't really care that this is in my library, but if anyone were to buy this game seperate please, I beg of  you don't buy it, and buy DMC4 seperate as it is worth the money.Do yourself a favor and go buy the console version or the DMC HD collection, or emulate it, whatever. Its really upsetting that this game is still up for sale and Valve won't take it down because they want to have DMC games in their library. Trust me, you'll love yourself for buying the console version instead of this poor excuse of a port that hasn't been updated forever.EDIT: So I found out that there is a mod that does fix the support for controls and video settings. BUT my review still stands as a thumbs down as no one should buy this game full price just for a third party mod. Just get the console version with the HD Collection.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												Let me start this review by saying I didn't play this game anywhere near launch (started only recently), and have had very little experience with the Devil May Cry series before I started playing this game. I did have experience playing God of War, Ninja Gaiden Sigma and the like before however, so I'm familiar with the Hack & Slash genre.With that said, here is my review. You're free to disagree with my points (I'd be more glad if you did agree though :)) as this is my personal opinion.First of all, the story. I kinda liked it, although it wasn't unusually gripping or emotional.  I don't want to spoil anything to people who haven't played it yet, but I will say that thanks to Dante's entertaining persona, the memorable bosses, and a few nice plot twists I didn't expect, it's one of the better plots for this type of game I came across. 7/10The gameplay. This game has the best combat I've ever seen in this type of game, with great flow, especially on Turbo mode. Trying out different load-outs (there are plenty of combinations of arms, and most weapons are unique and fun to use) and styles (essentially a selectable special move to go along with your weapons) is addicting, and enemies (bosses in particular) are varied and require different strategies rather than repetitive mashing or QTEs to beat (looking at you, God of War). Exploration and puzzles were a bit too simplistic for me most of the time, but helped make this game feel more like a grand adventure than a static arena.The controls in the game however are problematic. While I've got them to work perfectly with my Logitech F310 (in D-Input mode) and Net Way PS3/PC Gamepad, This game doesn't support Xbox 360 and One controllers without some tweaking, so I recommend having an older, Direct-Input controller to play with as Keyboards aren't optimal for this type of game. 10/10 (with a gamepad, otherwise 6. yeah, it's that important)The graphics of the game are showing their age; it is a relatively old game, and doesn't support high resolutions. Also, the graphics of this version are inferior to the PS2 and HD Collection versions as some of the more advanced lighting and shadowing effects are missing, and there is some very mild lag in some areas. The game is still perfectly fun and playable with these faults, but it's still something to keep in mind though if you care a lot about visuals. The character and environment designs however were pretty good for their time, and still have a bit of charm, even today. (7/10)The music here is a mixed bag: I'm not a fan of the heavy-metal esque battle themes, although they fit the setting of the game. The rest of the music, like ambient sounds and effects are immersive however, and the goddess statue and final boss themes were very nice IMO. (6.5/10, although if you like the battle themes you might give an 8 or a 9)Finally replayability. This game isn't very long (about 12 hours for my first playthrough) but has immense replay value, with a lot of harder difficulty levels to unlock and test your skills with, an alternate playable character with unique weapons (Vergil), the ability to carry your upgrades and items from playthrough to playthrough, and the Bloody Palace, an arena with near endless battles, this game can keep you busy for a very long time if you want to master it. 10/10.Verdict: DMC3 SE is a fantastic game, with a ton of replay value. If you have a gamepad and don't mind a minor graphical downgrade, this is a solid reccomendation. If you're with a keyboard though or want the best graphics available, I'd recommend getting the PS2 version/HD remake if you can. Even if you can't, there's still a very solid game here. (No final score, as there are too many variables depending on your hardware and everyone has their own priorities in games. I only try to advise. Who am I to judge what you find important?)

												Recommended but for fans only ! I would even say fans that don't mind putting some effort into fixing the problems. It's a pretty bad port ! Be advise of what you're getting. Things that don't work as expected :  Dualshock 3 not detected (setup as a 360 controller with DS3/Better DS3. Work in every game but this one).  Can't launch in fullscreen. Got to press alt+enter everytime. Resolution isn't saved. Got to set it to 1280x960 everytime (That's the maximum, original 4:3 format mind you). There's some clipping on both side of the screen when in fullscreen. Ok so that's my complaint after just got out of the shop and facing that 3 headed dog. I ended mapping all the keyboard buttons on my Steam Controller and it works well enough. Gotta say that I'm a fan of the serie, played them all back on the PS2, PS3 and now on PC. This port is just really really bad but if you put some effort, you can make it work with patches and fixes by the community. Just know what you're getting into. Be advised !!

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												This game is a bit unenjoyable.I think we have all heard it's one of the worst ports of remembrance.You can actually play the game with default settings with the controller.You have to hold the x-box controller a little different to where your left thumb is on the right control stick.To play in full screen hold down at the same time the ALT & ENTER buttons.You also can't change the gun on the fly.Gun changing has to be done through the menu.Other than those hassles  it's something you should be able to adjust to.I'm playing on easy and once I have that down I might try it on higher setting.The reason I say NO to the game is that  there are better choices of DMC on PC.They all play the same.So don't listen to people say this is the best on PS2 when the makers have stood by the same formula with all current DMC games.This game is playable as is. No need to download a bunch of MODS unless you know what your doing.I've seen many people mess up thier PC's  and games with MODS.Many PC elitist will call you an idiot for not knowing how to install MODS and try to sway you to be using them.DMC 3 is a more advanced MODS for the user.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												With a little bit of effort and the Style Switcher mod, this title is a great alternative to the PS2 version.  This is still one of my favorite action games to date, and the gameplay is still challenging.  However, you will have to do some work if you want it to work.It's made even more dynamic with the ability to expand on Virgil and switch styles on the fly (using mods).For those who have never played a Devil May Cry title, this is arguably the best of them all.  Though there's options to start on Easy, the game can become extremely challenging.  Once you clear one difficulty, the next one is unlocked.  The hardest difficulty gets extremely hard with more enemies in each level, faster enemies that deal more damage, bosses with fatal (or near) attacks, and if you don't clear enemies quickly, the become much harder to kill.I think this is one of Capcom's best titles, even though the voice-acting and cutscenes are corny.  Controller extremely highly recommended.

content:
Posted: January 29
												The game itself is good.  However, getting it to play nice with a 360 controller and finding a decent resolution is a chore.  But I thought it was worth it in the end.This link posted by another reviewer helped me get setup: http://www.nexusmods.com/devilmaycry3/mods/1/?I think this is what worked for me to get the 360 controller to work correctly with the game.  Hope it helps some future player:[Controller (XBOX 360 Wireless Receiver for Windows)]START = 7SELECT = 6CIRCLE = 1TRIANGLE = 3SQUARE = 2CROSS = 0L1 = 4R1 = 5L2 = 11R2 = 12L3 = 8R3 = 9L<->R = 1

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 16
												Initially I gave this game a worse review, since it's still an atrocious port of one of the character action greats. It's got no fullscreen option, bad controller support, occasional slowdowns and bugged music in some parts. Playing this on a Playstation 2, or playing the HD collection is obviously the better option.That said, I managed to play this game in its entirety by fiddling with my controller (one of those cheap Logitech gamepads with input options) and setting my computer's power option to High Performance. Once I did the latter, the game ran almost perfectly, but with no fullscreen. If you're willing to try your luck with this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥or you have the patience to install the Style Switcher mod, buy this port on sale.Otherwise, play it on a Playstation or emulate it.
